item.title: On Structured Content
item.description:
I’m forcing myself to small-sized chunks of content.

There’s also two experiments I’d like to make, linking bits of my opinions to the others:

  1. make their relationships obvious
  2. not mixing ideas and having them as atomic as possible
  3. finding myself which bits of my philosophy most shape my ideas
  4. finding which bits of my philosophy are most useful / explain most things
  5. running a PageRank or reverse-PageRank algo on it to find the “roots” of it

I suppose this requires a discipline and a lot of rework I probably won’t be able / courageous enough to make. But it’d be nice to try, and if someone else does it I’d find it interesting and motivating :)

Cheers,

item.title: Own your content
item.description:
I didn’t particularly want to make a blog, but I love to share. So I guess it’s time I give a proper home to my content.

Facebook, Twitter, Google all stripped us of our content. “Content is king”, but they have none of their own.

Many movements propose we take back control of our data and content. This is an experiment in just that. Join me if you care :)

item.title: The Blogging Ego
item.description:
In here as in life, I hope I don’t have much ego showing. Being proud and confident is nice but ego has a tendency to show up and ruin good things.

When blogs were hip I was being even more hipster by despising them. Sorry, teenage years. On the other hand, nobody had to suffer the bad content I would have written then.

Now I have created enough content I want to share, mostly - talks I made at events and conferences - translations of content I thought should be shared in french - questions I’ve been asked enough times to structure

so it’s not really a blogging ego, rather a way to get back control of my content and “being the change I want to bring the world”.

So for now the biggest effort I’m putting in there is just reducing posts to bite-sized chunks. I have an horrible tendency to make things huge and ugly, so I’ll leave it at that.

Cheers,

item.title: On Intellectual Property
item.description:
I don’t believe in inviolable, enforcable Intellectual Property. I feel people who create content for others should be able to live decently, but that’s because I feel everyone should live decently.

Some people write things nobody wants to read, or buy. Most IP and legal stuff I’ve seen badly protect content that needn’t be, for the wrong reasons. Nobody feels bad for a merchant selling rotten goods. I’m a bad writer, so well… I have a real job.

item.title: I share things
item.description:
We all grow by sharing. Ideas grow by being shared.

I think “whose idea it was in the first place” is barely relevant. It’s nice to know where ideas comes from: time, country, socioeconomic status, path the idea took in cultures to get where it is today. But we’re products of our times.

I stole people’s ideas, you’ll be stealing mine. This may or not be conscious. Sometimes, bad luck, you put hard work into expressing new ideas in a new way, only to find someone else already did it elsewhere, days or centuries before.

This is why this whole site is CC-BY-SA. It’s on GitHub and I left enough means to contact me, so feel free to do just that.

item.title: I have opinions
item.description:
Many. On many topics.

They all mostly respect the following rules: 1. they’re mine 1. nobody else’s 1. yours may differ and that’s fine 1. they’re not my employer’s or customers’

  1. they’re open to debate
    1. it’s part of the publishing game - but if you debate, play by the debate rules
      1. a person is not a single thought - nobody is a piece of shit for an opinion
      2. I wrote them to share so I feel either entitled to them or curious
  2. they may be wrong
    1. they may reflect lots of ignorance on a topic
      1. they may be badly written - even if you don’t like my words, perhaps we agree
      2. they may reflect a different point of view - many things depend on circumstances
    2. feel free to politely correct me
      1. patience, politeness but most of all proven facts can change my opinion
      2. I’m not so important they should be enough to upset you
    3. if something is wrong enough, we should talk over a nice tea or beer
